data.title: Pistons GT — the one Detroit pro sports team to clinch playoff berth
data.meta_description: The Detroit Pistons fielded one of best teams in inaugural NBA 2K season and will try to bring home the title later this month.
data.text:
Seven go-karts roared around the Novi track Tuesday afternoon.

The race was never in doubt — the No. 6 car dusted all six pursuers.

But the outing at JD Racing wasn’t about competition.

It was a moment of celebration.

The Pistons Gaming Team was enjoying downtime after clinching a playoff spot in the inaugural season of the NBA’s esports league.

After wrapping up at the track — gamer Fred Mendoza took the flag — Pistons GT esports manager Adam Rubin and the organization was going to treat the team to a bowling outing.

Not exactly a Champagne bath, but when the NBA 2K team won’t have another off day until its playoff journey ends, team members will take it.

The berth represents validation for Rubin, who devised the team’s draft strategy.

He was confident the team — which sits third at 9-4 in the 17-team league with one week remaining in the regular season — would be good.

But he didn’t feel vindication.

He felt relief — and he thinks the best is yet to come.

“We've learned — and I constantly remind them — that we still have yet to play our best game without any mistakes and it's going to come a time where they all click at the right time,” Rubin said.

Rising to occasion

The Pistons were struggling to seal the spot.

In their first chance to clinch on Saturday, second-place Philadelphia 76ers crushed Pistons GT by 24 points at the league’s New York City studio where games are played each weekend.

The team had a second chance against Orlando Magic Gaming, which sits in fifth place.

The teams were locked in a tight game when a member of the Magic trash talked the Pistons’ best player, power forward Ramo Radoncic.

It was on.

“That kind of got me riled up,” Radoncic said. “I wanted this even badder than I did before so I had to make the next big play.”

And when one his teammates nailed a key 3-pointer, Radocic let the Magic player hear about it.

“You talking?” he taunted.

“That was basically the play of the game. The whole game was a dogfight, especially in that fourth quarter. Just to get that win was so much adrenaline, so much emotion for all of us.”

It was extra special for Radoncic because his older brother was there to watch. Radoncic and his family are from Brooklyn.

After the game, social media started promoting Radoncic for the league’s first MVP award.

Rubin promoted Radoncic’s candidacy, citing how the four players selected before him in the inaugural draft will likely fail to lead their teams to the playoffs.

Radoncic, 26, who is among the league leaders, averaging nearly 20 points, 9.6 rebounds and nearly two steals per game, isn’t worried about individual goals.

“It would be an honor to be the MVP of the league,” Radoncic said. “It just lets you know you’re one of the top players in the league.

“Honestly, I don’t care about it too much. I just want to win the championship. That’s the main goal.”

What’s next?

The Pistons have a chance at gaining the second seed of the eight-team postseason, which begins Aug. 17.

At 9-4, they are tied with the 76ers, who hold the tiebreaker.

The Pistons finish Friday against the lowly Golden State Warriors (yeah, that’s right) Gaming Squad (2-10).

The 76ers face the Utah Jazz Gaming in the game before the Pistons’, so the game could hold meaning.

The quarterfinals will be single-elimination, while the semifinals and league finals will be best of three.

The entire prize pool for the playoffs is $600,000 and the champion receives $300,000.

A nice potential bonus for the players, who are under contract for six months and salaries of more than $30,000.

The league hasn’t determined how it will approach expansion and how franchises will be able to protect top players.

The players, who gathered as strangers in April shortly after the draft, will head home as close friends. The players share two residences.

Some left steady jobs. Mendoza said recently he will earn money via ridesharing when he returns to the Washington, D.C area.

But it might be a short break.

Rubin said the league is also exploring an earlier start to next season after the first season kicked off in May — maybe as early as January.

An earlier start would allow for seasons to more closely align with the release of NBA 2K, which occurs annually in September.

It would also allow for players to feel more part of organizations with infrastructure designed to be active during the regular NBA season.

But first, there’s a title to win.

Radoncic said Pistons vice chairman Arn Tellem has promised a special memento.

Tellem will get Radoncic a championship belt — Rasheed Wallace-style — if the team can win it all. Tellem confirmed this via text.

Radoncic told Tellem he likes to talk trash — kind of like Wallace when he was starring for the Pistons.

Wallace would wear a title belt after the Pistons won the 2004 NBA title.

“He told me he was going to get me the Rasheed Wallace belt,” Radoncic said. “He told me if you win, I promise I can get you that belt. That’s an add on right there.”
